Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Record of Early Cretaceous Growth of the Nevadaplano From Syn-orogenic Deposits of the Sevier Hinterland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers have long been interested in mountain belts and the processes that create them. The Cordillera of the western United States has long been interpreted as a mountain belt that developed in response to subduction of oceanic crust beneath continental crust. Despite being a "type" mountain belt, however, questions remain about the timing and magnitude of surface uplift during much of the prolonged duration of subduction off of the west coast of North America during the Mesozoic. Intensive study of the South American Andes has led some to suggest that surface uplift lags behind the shortening that occurs in response to subduction; this runs counter to the conventional wisdom that surface uplift and shortening should occur in tandem with each other. This study aims to provide an estimate of surface elevation relatively early in the Cordilleran mountain building event, during which a large amount of shortening took place. This estimate, combined with existing surface elevation estimates from the end of the Cordilleran event and at greatest levels of crustal thickening, should enable us to determine whether surface uplift occurred after or in tandem with shortening during the Mesozoic. These results have the potential to teach us a great deal about the response of the lithosphere to subduction in different types of mountain belts, which has broad implications for seismic activity and hazards. In addition, because we use ancient climate data to estimate ancient elevations, this project will provide valuable insight into ancient climate conditions during a relatively warm period in Earth's history, and also how animals and plants respond to both climate and elevation change through time. Museum displays at the Las Vegas Natural History Museum and Sierra College (Rocklin, CA), will inform visitors about the new findings related to mountain development, as well as Mesozoic plants and animals which once inhabited the area. Other important societal outcomes include providing support for three early career researchers; broadening of participation in an important STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) discipline; and development of research infrastructure. Results of the research will be presented in the peer-reviewed scientific literature and at professional science meetings; analytical data will be made available via publically accessible community data repositories.

To determine surface elevation in central Nevada during the Early Cretaceous, the project team will use conventional and "clumped" stable isotope geochemistry to estimate ancient temperature and stable isotope composition of water. These data will then be compared to similar datasets from the time-equivalent Cedar Mountain Formation in Utah (a study in progress) in order to estimate hinterland paleoelevation. These data will be integrated with sedimentology, paleontology, palynology, geologic mapping and tuff geochronology to provide critical context about the ancient environment of the region that will bolster the interpretations of the geochemical records and improve the resulting paleoelevation estimates. When placed in the existing framework of the timing and magnitude of crustal shortening that occurred during the Sevier orogeny, the paleoelevation estimates will be used to distinguish between three surface elevation scenarios, each with distinct geodynamic implications. Surface elevations of 1-2 kilometers are predicted directly from the shortening history, assuming that isostatic compensation accompanied crustal thickening throughout the duration of shortening. Elevations lower than this would imply that crustal thickening coincided with generation of dense lower lithosphere, and elevations higher than this would suggest that removal of dense lithosphere operated early during orogenesis. The results of this study will provide valuable insight into the range of lithospheric processes that operate during subduction-related orogenesis as well as provide valuable ancient climate data for the western United States. In addition, this study will push paleoaltimetry farther back in time than existing datasets, so modifications we make to typical approaches used in paleoaltimetry to determine these very ancient paleoelevations will be valuable for pushing paleoaltimetry estimates in other orogenic systems further back in time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Models proposed for expansive mountain belts such as the North American Cordillera, which includes the Western U.S. Rocky Mountains, attempt to describe relationships between several important processes that operated during mountain building. In the Western U.S. in Nevada and Utah, several geologists propose that a high-elevation plateau, nicknamed the ?Nevadaplano? after comparison to the modern-day Andean Altiplano in Bolivia and Peru, had been constructed during mountain building. Geologists can obtain records of the elevations of mountain belts by analyzing the stable isotope values of sedimentary rocks and volcanic rocks that were deposited during mountain belt construction. In Nevada, sedimentary rocks and volcanic rocks that are between 65 and 25 million years old are widespread, and isotopic evidence from these rocks indicates they were deposited at high elevations (2-3.5 km), and therefore that the Nevadaplano was high by that time. However, at present we have no record of when the plateau was uplifted, and at what rate. Solving this problem has importance for our understanding of the interactions between several processes that operate during mountain building, including the relationships between shortening of the crust and uplift of the land surface. To understand the record of building of the Nevadaplano, we need to make isotopic records from older sedimentary rocks that were deposited during mountain building in this region. In all of eastern and central Nevada, there is only one rock unit preserved that fits the bill: the Newark Canyon Formation, which consists of a series of isolated exposures of sandstone, conglomerate, and limestone deposited by streams and in small lakes and ponds.

In this project, our goals were to: 1) describe the rock types, environments of deposition, and timing of deposition of several exposures of the Newark Canyon Formation; 2) understand how the Newark Canyon Formation relates to faults and folds that built mountains in this region; and 3) analyze the isotopic composition of the Newark Canyon Formation to determine the causes of changing environments, temperatures in the region at the time, and the elevation at which the environments formed. The overarching goal is to use this information to understand how and when the Nevadaplano was constructed, and explore what this means for mountain building processes in North America.

Over the duration of this project, we produced geologic maps of four different Newark Canyon Formation exposures, and made field observations that allowed us to relate their deposition to the construction of folds and motion on faults. We dated mineral grains from Newark Canyon Formation rocks that allowed us to determine that deposition took place in the middle part of the Cretaceous Period, between ~120 and ~95 million years ago. These observations and dates indicate that shortening of the crust was occurring in central Nevada at the same time as shortening to the east in western Utah. This tells us that mountain building was dynamic in space and time, and jumped back and forth between the frontal, eastern part of the mountain belt, and interior of the mountain belt to the west.[KS1] [KS2] 

The Newark Canyon Formation nearest to Eureka, Nevada, includes numerous limestones that formed in ancient ponds and lakes. These rocks can yield isotopic records that help inform us about ancient climate in the area and the elevation of the region. Before measuring the isotope values of the samples, we examined the limestones in close detail to determine information about water depth and conditions in the ponds and lakes, and overall changes in the environment of this region during the time of mountain building. The environment changed from a region with medium energy rivers with adjacent ponds, to a region with higher energy rivers that deposited a lot of coarse-grained sediment. The region then changed into a large, shallow lake before finally changing back into a high-energy river system. These changes likely occurred in response to the variable strength of mountain building in this region, which we learned about from examining nearby faults and folds. Measurements of the isotope values of the limestones suggest that climate in the region was warm and wet. The climate and animals that lived in the region at the time (inferred from fossils found in the area) are similar to climate inferred from sedimentary rocks and fossils of similar age to the east, in central Utah. This suggests that both areas were at similar elevation at the time the rocks formed, and likely at relatively low elevation. Together with the results of our investigation of the faults and folds in the area, this suggests that mountain building in the area had started to create elevation, but that a high elevation plateau like the modern Andean Altiplano did not yet exist.

This project involved training of undergraduate and graduate students at Washington State University, the University of Colorado, Boulder, and the University of Nevada, Las Vegas.
